He gestured vaguely towards the press line, a cluster of cameras and microphones held at bay by a line of uniformed officers a hundred yards away.

Astor finally turned, her expression unreadable. "We have a book," she said flatly. "A confession. A manifesto. Written by the killer." Davies's eyes lit up with a predatory gleam, instantly seeing the media potential. Astor cut him off before he could speak. "It's also written in the victim's own blood. Sir." The words hit him like a physical blow. The colour drained from his face, and for the first time, a flicker of genuine horror broke through his polished veneer. He looked from Astor to the blanket and back again, his mouth opening and closing silently.

"My God," he whispered, finally seeming to grasp the scale of the depravity they were facing. "We can't release that. It would cause a full-blown panic. The town would tear itself apart."

"No, sir. We can't," Astor agreed, a grim satisfaction in seeing him finally understand. "What you can tell them is that we have a significant lead, a piece of evidence that is unique to the killer. Tell them Sergeant Astor is leading the investigation and that we will not rest. Tell them to keep their children inside." The last sentence was an order, not a suggestion. She was already turning away from him, her focus returning to the meticulous, painstaking work of the scene. Davies was a distraction, a political problem. The real problem was a poet who used blood for ink, and she had a book to read.

The incident room was a pressure cooker, the air thick with the smell of stale coffee and rising fear. Phones rang with a frantic, unanswered persistence. Uniformed officers and plainclothes detectives moved with a tense energy, their faces drawn and pale under the harsh fluorescent lights. At the center of this controlled chaos, on a large table cleared of all but a single evidence box, lay the book. Astor, now in her own uniform of severe black trousers and a grey jumper that did nothing to soften her edges, stood over it. The cold of the river had been replaced by the dry, sterile chill of the station, but the deeper cold, the one that had seeped in at the playground, remained lodged in her soul.

“Kenji’s preliminary report is in,” Detective Sergeant Miles Corbin said, dropping a thin folder onto the corner of the table. Corbin was her unofficial second, a man whose cynicism was so profound it almost looped back around to being a form of optimism; he assumed the worst of humanity, so he was never disappointed. He was short, rumpled, and had a face that looked like it had been slept in for a week, but his eyes were sharp. “The ink is as you suspected. Human blood. Type O-positive. Matches the sample from the victim. The paper is high-grade rag-and-pulp, expensive stuff. The binding is real leather, likely calfskin. Old, but well-cared for. No prints on the cover or the page you touched, just your own glove-smear. He’s careful. Or he’s wearing gloves.”

Astor nodded, not looking up from the high-resolution photographs of the book’s first page splayed across the table. The spidery script was mesmerizing in its precision. “He’s not just careful, Miles. He’s a performer. This is theatre.” She tapped a finger on one of the photographed words: *chittering*. “Look at the language. It’s archaic. ‘Chittering glee.’ ‘Porcelain throat.’ He’s not a common thug. He’s educated. He reads.” She looked around the room, at the faces of her team. Peters was by the coffee machine, looking like he was about to be sick. “I want every library, every bookstore, every university literature department in a hundred-mile radius checked. We're looking for someone who buys or borrows books on folklore, gothic poetry, obscure fairy tales. Someone with an interest in antiquated language.”

Corbin grunted. “That’s half the English faculty at Milton University.” But he was already making a note. “What about the previous victims? Tim Jennings and Chloe Swift. Their bodies were also staged, but he never left anything this… personal.” Astor’s mind flashed to the previous two scenes. Tim, found by the canal lock, a toy boat clutched in his hand. Chloe, seated on the war memorial in the town square, a crown of autumn leaves on her head. The police had assumed the objects were things the children had with them when they were taken. Now, she wasn't so sure. “He called Lily ‘a silly, fragile thing’,” Astor mused, her voice low. “The daisy, the book... he’s creating a narrative for each one. We weren't just finding victims, Miles. We were finding finished chapters.”

The thought was sickening. The killer hadn’t escalated by leaving a book; he had simply decided to share the text of a story he was already writing. She pulled on a fresh pair of gloves and, with excruciating care, lifted the actual book from its evidence box. The lab had photographed every page, but she needed to feel it, to see the words as he had written them. She turned past the first entry about Lily, her stomach clenching, and found the next page. Another entry, in the same elegant script and the same horrifying ink.

*The second song was one of earth and stone. A boy with knees perpetually scuffed and a laugh like gravel in a tin can. His name was Timothy. A solid, stoic name. He smelled of mud and the promise of rain. I found him by the lock, where the water is patient and deep. He did not flutter. He was a stone, and I let him sink into the silence he was destined for. His final breath was a gasp of surprise, a small puff of cloud in the autumn air. I kept it. It is mine. Written here, in the ink of his own grounding.*

Astor felt a jolt, a connection snapping into place. *The ink of his own grounding.* Timothy Jennings. The second victim. His blood type had been A-negative. The book contained more than one entry. She flipped the page again. *A crown for a queen of fallen leaves. Chloe. A name like a whisper. Her hair was spun gold, and she carried the scent of woodsmoke and bonfire night…* Astor closed the book with a sharp snap. It wasn't a journal he'd *started* with Lily. It was a collection he'd brought up to date. He'd gone back, written entries for his previous victims in their own blood. The logistics of it were staggering. The sheer, calculated evil of it was breathtaking. "Get me the evidence logs for the Jennings and Swift cases," she commanded, her voice ringing with a new, terrible urgency. "Everything. I need to know what Kenji's team recovered from their bodies. Every sample. Now." The Goblin hadn't just left them a book. He'd left them a ledger. And somewhere in its pages, he would have made a mistake. He had to.

## Chapter 2

Corbin moved without a word, a man galvanized. Astor's order had cut through the room's high-strung hum, giving it a vector. Within minutes, two large, dusty archive boxes were thudded onto the table next to the pristine evidence container holding the Goblin’s ledger. The contrast was stark: the banal, bureaucratic history of two dead children next to the vibrant, horrifying art made from their endings. Peters, looking grateful for a task that involved movement rather than thought, began laying out the files in chronological order, his hands clumsy with reverence and dread. The thick folders for Timothy Jennings and Chloe Swift, cold cases for six and four months respectively, were opened for the first time with a new and terrible context.

Astor bypassed the witness statements and geographical profiles, the dead ends and frustrated suppositions. She went straight for the coroner’s reports and the forensic summaries from Kenji’s lab. The pages were cold and clinical, filled with measurements, toxicology results, and Latin terms that sought to impose order on the incomprehensible. *Cause of death: asphyxiation, mechanism undetermined.* It was the same for both. No ligature marks, no signs of blunt force trauma, no water in the lungs. It was as if they had simply been persuaded to stop breathing. A chilling echo of the book’s words: *I quieted it.* She scanned the dry text, her eyes hunting for the detail that the original investigation, lacking the Goblin’s monstrous Rosetta Stone, would have missed.

“Here,” she said, her voice so quiet it barely disturbed the air. She tapped a sentence in the appendix of Chloe Swift’s autopsy report. Corbin and Peters leaned in. The line was buried in a section listing minor post-mortem observations. *‘Single puncture mark noted on the medial aspect of the left wrist. Approx. 1mm diameter. Consistent with insect bite or thorn scratch. Deemed non-contributory.’* Astor’s gloved finger slid across the tabletop to Timothy Jennings’s file. It took her another minute of scanning, her focus absolute. “And here. On the boy. *‘Small lesion discovered on the sole of the right foot, posterior heel. Clean margins. Likely from stepping on sharp detritus prior to death.’*”

Corbin straightened up slowly, his perpetually tired face draining of what little colour it had. He ran a hand through his thinning hair, the cynical armour he wore every day cracking under the strain. “My God, Astor. He used a needle. A hypodermic. He drew their blood after he killed them. He took a sample.” The implication hung in the air, thick and suffocating. The killer didn't just place his victims; he tended to them. He harvested from them. The scenes at the canal lock and the war memorial were not just dumping grounds; they were temporary workshops.

A new wave of cold washed over Astor, colder than the Milt, colder than the morgue. This was a new dimension of violation. The staging of the bodies was for the world, for the police, for the papers. The daisy and the toy boat were props for the audience. But the drawing of the blood, the secret, meticulous collection—that was for him. That was the private part of the ritual. It was the act that enabled the creation of his true masterpiece, the leather-bound book that now sat like a venomous toad on her conference table. He wasn't just a collector of silence; he was a curator of death, and he required authentic materials for his exhibit.

“He’s not just arrogant,” Astor said, her voice hard as she pushed the files away. “He’s disciplined. This requires knowledge. A steady hand. It’s a procedure.” She looked at her team, their faces a gallery of shock and dawning horror. This was the turning point. The monster now had a potential shape. “Miles, get on it. I want a list of every person in Milton and the surrounding shires with medical training who has left their job or been fired in the last five years. Doctors, nurses, paramedics, veterinarians, phlebotomists. And add embalmers and taxidermists to that list. Anyone whose profession involves needles, anatomy, and a certain… detachment.”

The room snapped into a new kind of action. Phones were picked up with renewed purpose. Keyboards began to clatter. The formless dread now had a target, a tangible line of inquiry. The Goblin was no longer a supernatural fiend from a fairy tale; he was a man with a specific, identifiable skillset. He had bled his victims, and in doing so, he had bled a clue. Astor turned back to the table, to the high-resolution photographs of the book's hateful, elegant script. The words had not lost their horror, but they were now imbued with something else: information. She was no longer just reading a confession. She was reading a technical manual, a psychological blueprint left by an adversary who believed himself to be an artist. And every artist, she knew, had a tell.

While the incident room buzzed with the frantic energy of the hunt, Astor drew a circle of silence around herself and the killer’s words. She had the lab’s full digital copy of the book on a tablet now, the pages scanned in such high definition she could see the microscopic fibres of the paper and the way the blood-ink had feathered at the edges of the elegant script. She read past the entries for Lily, Timothy, and Chloe, her mind a cold engine of analysis, refusing to be swayed by the lyrical horror. She was looking for the tell. Not just in what he said, but in how he said it. The cadence was deliberate, almost poetic. The vocabulary was rich and obscure. He was performing on the page, creating a persona as meticulously as he staged his victims.

She forced herself to read the entry for Chloe Swift again. *A crown for a queen of fallen leaves.* The police had found Chloe on the town's war memorial, seated on the stone bench. Astor remembered the detail from the initial report: a circlet of oak and maple leaves had been placed on her head. At the time, it had been dismissed as a bizarre but random flourish. Now, Astor saw it was a title. He was anointing his victims. The toy boat with Timothy Jennings—the book described him as a ‘stone’ sinking into the ‘patient and deep’ water of the lock. He hadn't been holding the boat; the killer had placed it there as an epitaph. Each crime scene was a tableau, a living illustration for the chapter he was writing. This wasn't a series of murders. It was a collection of short stories, and the book was the anthology.

Her phone vibrated on the table, a stark buzz that broke her concentration. It was Kenji. “Astor,” she answered, her eyes still fixed on the tablet. “What have you got for me?”

“Something odd about the book itself,” Kenji’s voice was crisp, energized by a puzzle. “Corbin told you the paper was old, high-grade stock, likely late nineteenth-century. That’s correct. But the book wasn’t *made* in the nineteenth century. The binding is new. The stitching that holds the signatures together is modern nylon thread, unnaturally strong. And the glue used on the spine and to fix the leather to the boards… it’s a commercial PVA. You could buy it at any craft store. The cover is old calfskin, yes, but it’s been repurposed from something else. There are faint impressions on the inside, ghost-writing, suggesting it was once the cover of a different, larger ledger.”

Astor sat back, the new information slotting into place with a sickening click. The Goblin hadn’t found an antique diary. He had built one. He had sourced the old paper, stripped the leather from another volume, and bound it himself. He was a craftsman. A bookbinder. The thought added another layer to his profile: patience, precision, a workshop. A private, secret place where he could practice his grotesque art, stitching pages and storing blood. He wasn’t a goblin from a fairy tale. He was a man with a hobby.

“He’s building his own mythology, Kenji,” she said softly. “From scratch.” She ended the call and looked up, her gaze sweeping across the incident room. The search for medical professionals had ballooned into a search for literary experts, and now, a third, more esoteric category was needed: artisans. Bookbinders, restorers, conservationists. The circles on the Venn diagram were slowly, glacially, beginning to overlap. It felt like hunting for a ghost in a city of fog.

Just then, Corbin approached, holding a single sheet of paper as if it were a bomb. His cynical façade was gone, replaced by an expression of pure, focused intensity. “Sergeant. We might have something.” He laid the paper on the table. It was a printout of a personnel file. “The search for medical professionals turned up a lot of noise. But we cross-referenced it with staff and faculty lists from Milton University, going back ten years. One name popped.” He tapped the paper. “Julian Croft. He was a conservation technician at the university’s rare books library for six years. His job was literally repairing and rebinding antique texts.”

Astor’s heart hammered a sudden, hard rhythm against her ribs. It was a hit. A solid one. “Was a technician? Why did he leave?”

“Fired,” Corbin said, his voice grim. “Three years ago. For ‘misappropriation of archival materials.’ In layman’s terms, he was caught stealing. Not books. Scraps. Discarded pages of antique paper, offcuts of vellum, fragments of old leather bindings. His supervisor thought he was a harmless eccentric building a scrapbook. They didn't press charges, just terminated his employment.” He paused, letting the weight of it sink in before delivering the final blow. “Before he worked at the library, he was a student at the university medical school. Dropped out in his final year. His specialization was hematology.”

## Chapter 3

The name hung in the air of the incident room like a particle of dust caught in a sunbeam: Julian Croft. For a moment, the frantic hum of the investigation ceased, replaced by a profound, collective intake of breath. The Goblin, the ghost, the creature of shadow and ruin, was suddenly reduced to a personnel file. He had a history, a former address, a reason he was fired. The abstract evil had coalesced into a tangible target, and the shift in the room was seismic. The air, thick with despair, was now charged with the electric thrill of the hunt.

“Find him,” Astor’s voice was low and resonant, cutting through the silence. It wasn’t a shout, but it carried the force of a physical blow. “I want a current address, vehicle registration, known associates, financial activity, everything. He was fired three years ago. Where has he been? How has he been living? Peters, get a warrant for his last known address, and any property under his name. Now.” The rookie, galvanized, scrambled to the phone, his earlier nausea replaced by the fire of purpose. Corbin was already at a whiteboard, scrawling CROFT in thick black marker, a spiderweb of connections already starting to branch out from the name. He was no longer a goblin; he was a problem to be solved.

The digital manhunt began in earnest. Detectives hunched over keyboards, their faces illuminated by the pale glow of their monitors as they plundered databases. The initial results were frustratingly thin. Croft’s last known address was a small flat above a bakery he’d vacated two and a half years ago. His bank account had been closed, his driving license had expired. There were no credit cards, no mobile phone contracts, no utility bills. For the last thirty months, Julian Croft had, to all official purposes, ceased to exist. He lived like a ghost, meticulously erasing the trail of a modern life, a discipline that spoke volumes of his foresight and patience.

“He’s living off the grid, Sergeant,” Corbin reported, rubbing his tired eyes. “Cash only. No footprint.” Astor stared at the whiteboard, at the name surrounded by dead ends. A man this precise, this dedicated to his craft, wouldn’t be living in a ditch. He needed a space. A workshop. “He wouldn’t rent,” she reasoned aloud, thinking of the book, the stolen scraps, the need for privacy. “Renting leaves a trail, landlords ask questions. He’d own. Or he’d occupy.” The word sparked an idea. She turned to Corbin. “Check property records again. Not just purchases. Inheritances. Family properties. Anything that might have passed to him off-market.” It took another hour of painstaking work, delving into dusty municipal archives and wills, before the hit came. A young detective, barely older than Peters, let out a sharp cry of success. “Got him, Sarge. A property transferred to Julian Croft from the estate of his grandfather. It’s an old industrial building. Downstream from the town, on the river Milt. A former tannery.”

The drive was silent and fraught with tension. Astor sat in the passenger seat of the lead tactical vehicle, the world outside sliding past in a blur of green and grey. The river Milt, her church, was now the path to hell. The location was perfect in its awfulness: isolated, forgotten by the town, its original purpose steeped in the chemical treatment of dead things. It was a place designed for foul smells and unsavoury work, a place no one would approach without reason. As they turned off the main road onto a pitted, overgrown track, the building came into view. It was a two-story brick monolith, its windows dark and blind, a chimney stack rising like a broken finger against the bruised sky. It didn’t look evil; it just looked empty, a hollowed-out husk from a different century.

Astor was the first out of the vehicle, pulling on her tactical vest over her jumper. The air here was different, heavy with the phantom scent of brine and chemicals, of damp earth and river rot. “Standard entry,” the tactical team leader said, his voice a low thrum in his radio. “Astor, you stay behind my shield.” She shook her head, her gaze locked on the heavy oak door. “No. I’m going in with you. He knows me.” She didn’t know how she knew it, but the certainty was absolute. This whole performance, the book, the clues, it was a dialogue. And she was his audience. The battering ram struck the door once, twice, and with a scream of splintering wood, it burst inwards.

The smell hit them first. Not the expected stench of decay, but something far more unsettling. It was the sterile, sharp scent of antiseptic, mingled with the dry, papery aroma of old books and the sweet, cloying tang of PVA glue. The ground floor was a cavernous workshop, but it was the opposite of chaotic. It was immaculate. Tools for bookbinding—presses, bone folders, cutting shears, awls—were laid out on a long workbench in neat, gleaming rows, like a surgeon’s instruments. Stacks of antique paper were sorted by size and age on metal shelves. Bolts of leather and vellum were rolled and stored in categorized tubes. It was the lair of a master craftsman, a space of profound order and control. The only jarring note was a single child’s red tricycle, identical to the one at Miller’s Park, standing pristine in a corner, as if it were a piece of finished sculpture.

Astor moved past the tactical officers clearing the corners, her instincts pulling her towards a staircase at the back. The upper floor was different. This was his studio, his gallery. The air was colder here. One wall was covered in a macabre collage: candid photographs, taken from a great distance with a powerful lens. Lily on the swings. Timothy by the canal. Chloe in the town square. They were beautiful photos, capturing moments of unselfconscious joy. He hadn’t just stalked them; he had studied them, appreciated them, chosen them for his collection. On the opposite wall were anatomical charts of the human vascular system, next to framed pages of Gothic poetry. It was a museum of his obsessions: life, death, and the art that bound them.

And then she saw it. In the center of the room, on a large, white drafting table, illuminated by a single, brilliant architect’s lamp, was his current project. It wasn't a book. It was a large, single sheet of pristine vellum, weighted down at the corners. In the center of the sheet, a new entry had been started, the spidery script a stark, rusty brown against the creamy surface. *The fourth song will be of the wind…* Beside the vellum, laid out on a velvet cloth, was a phlebotomist's kit: a tourniquet, antiseptic wipes, and a single, terrifyingly clean hypodermic needle. Next to that lay a small, unfinished kite, its wooden spars waiting to be joined. But it was the item on the other side of the vellum that made the air freeze in Astor's lungs. It was an old, faded photograph in a simple silver frame. A picture of a young girl, perhaps ten years old, with short, dark hair and an intense, serious expression, holding a swimming medal. It was a photograph of a young Sergeant Astor. And propped against the frame was a small, hand-written note, penned in the same elegant, spidery script. It said: *I saved you the last chapter.*

For a long, silent moment, the world contracted to the dimensions of the drafting table. The tactical officers sweeping the lower floor, the crackle of the radio, the scent of antiseptic—it all dissolved into a dull, distant hum. There was only the stark white of the vellum, the rusty brown script, and the ghost of her own ten-year-old face staring up at her. The girl in the photo was fierce, proud, her small body already showing the dense, powerful build of a swimmer, her chin jutted out with a determination Astor had forgotten she ever possessed. He had found her past, dug it up, and laid it out on his workbench like another specimen. The note was not a threat. It was an invitation. An intimate, terrifying summons that bypassed the Sergeant and spoke directly to the girl who found solace in the cold, punishing water. The cold that had seeped into her bones in the playground was nothing compared to this. This was a violation that reached back through time, twisting her sanctuary, her one clean fight against the river’s current, into a stage for his final act.

“Sergeant? Upper floor is clear. No sign of the suspect.” The voice of the tactical team leader, calm and professional, shattered the spell. Astor flinched as if struck. Her hand, moving with a jerky, unnatural motion, swept the small silver frame and the handwritten note into the deep pocket of her vest. An instinctive, animal act of concealment. She could not let them see. She could not allow her own narrative, her own life, to become a piece of evidence in her own case file. To do so would be to surrender, to admit that he had already won a part of the battle. She turned from the table, her face a mask of stone, though behind her eyes a firestorm was raging. The sight of the half-finished kite, the neat medical kit, the whole obscene diorama of her own impending murder, was something she would carry alone.

“Good,” she managed, her voice a clipped rasp. “Bag everything. Every tool, every scrap of paper, every photograph on that wall. I want this place stripped to the brick. Kenji’s team on their way?” She was on autopilot, issuing the correct orders, her mind working on a separate, frantic track. Corbin was coming up the stairs, his heavy tread a familiar comfort. He took one look at the scene—the photos of the children, the charts, the pristine workbench—and then he looked at her. He saw it instantly. The rigid set of her shoulders, the slight tremor in her hand as she gestured towards the wall, the glacial stillness in her eyes that went beyond professional composure into something far more dangerous. He stopped beside her, his voice a low murmur for her ears only. “Astor? What is it? What did you find?”

Without a word, she led him to the far side of the room, out of the direct sightline of the other officers who were beginning the painstaking process of documentation. She pulled the frame and the note from her pocket. She didn’t offer them, just held them in her palm, letting him see. Corbin’s gaze dropped to the photo, his breath catching in his throat. He looked from the fierce-eyed girl in the picture to the hardened woman standing before him, and the connection was undeniable. Then he read the note. *I saved you the last chapter.* The cynical armour he wore every day vaporized, replaced by a raw, protective fury. “He’s been watching you. The river… your morning swims.” His voice was a choked whisper. “Davies will have a fit. He’ll pull you, put you in protective custody. You’re the target now.”

“No,” Astor said, her voice diamond-hard as she slid the items back into her pocket. The evidence of her own life was now a secret she carried. “He doesn’t want to kill me in a safe house, Miles. He wants to perform. This is a dialogue. And he’s just told me the location of the final scene.” Her mind was racing, connecting the pieces with a terrifying clarity. *The fourth song will be of the wind…* The kite. The water meadows where the children flew them. It was a challenge. A rendezvous. “He wants me to come to him. Alone. He’s telling me where to find him.” She was no longer just the investigator; she was a character in his story, the final, named protagonist. To step aside now would be to let him write the ending his way. The thought was intolerable. The hunt was no longer a professional duty; it was an act of personal reclamation. She would not be a collection. She would not be a song. She would be the silence that fell after his voice was extinguished forever.

Corbin’s words were a rope thrown to a woman already halfway over a cliff. *He’ll pull you.* The thought of Davies, with his polished shoes and political sensibilities, taking this from her, locking her away while his men blundered through the final act, was more horrifying than the needle on the velvet cloth. It would be the ultimate desecration. She would become a case file, a victim to be managed, her story told in sanitized reports and press briefings. Croft would win. He would have successfully curated her ending, turning her from the hunter into a protected, pitiable thing. Her rage, a cold, familiar companion, solidified into a wall of absolute refusal.

“He will only pull me if he knows,” Astor said, her voice dropping to a conspiratorial hush. She finally looked at Corbin, her eyes pleading for him to understand something that went beyond procedure, beyond the law. This was a personal debt. “Miles, this thing, this creature, he feeds on stories. He writes them in blood. He just made the mistake of trying to write mine. I am the only one who can finish this. If they take me out of the field, he’ll disappear. He’ll wait. He’ll find another child, and he’ll start a new book. We can’t let that happen.” She gestured back toward the drafting table, to the empty space where the photo had been. “He has given me the location and the time. It will be dawn. At the water meadows. He wants the symmetry of it.”

Corbin stared at her, the conflict warring across his crumpled face. Every instinct, every regulation screamed at him to take the evidence, to file the report, to protect his superior officer. It was the correct, sensible, and justifiable thing to do. But he had seen the way Astor worked, the almost supernatural focus she brought to the chaos of a crime. He had seen the ghosts she carried and the relentless way she hunted the people who made them. He looked at the photographs of the children on the wall, their bright, stolen lives pinned up like butterflies, and then at the fierce, unyielding woman beside him. He knew, with a certainty that chilled him to the marrow, that she was right. Croft had chosen his antagonist. To switch the players now would be to forfeit the game.

“This is career suicide, Astor,” he finally whispered, the words tasting like ash. It wasn’t a refusal. It was a warning. It was consent. A wave of profound relief washed through Astor, so potent it almost buckled her knees. She had her second. “What’s the plan? You can’t just walk out there and meet him for a chat. That room downstairs is the workshop of a man who leaves nothing to chance. That meadow will be a kill box.”

“I know,” she agreed. “Which is why you’re going to run the real investigation. I will go to Davies. I’ll tell him about Croft, the workshop, the bookbinding, the hematology. I’ll tell him our primary suspect is an artisan who stages his victims based on poetic themes. I’ll point to the kite and the reference to ‘wind’ as our strongest lead for his next move, but I’ll frame it as a general pattern, not a personal invitation. I’ll sell him on a massive, overt police presence at every open space and park in the Milton area.” She paused, her mind’s eye seeing the plan unfold. “He’ll want to be seen to be doing something. He’ll send uniformed teams everywhere. It’ll be a circus. And while the Goblin is watching the show, watching the clumsy, public search for him, you will take a small, handpicked tactical team. The best ones. You will go to the water meadows before I do. You will be my ghost in the reeds. He’ll be watching for a police response. He won’t be watching for me.” It was a breathtaking gamble, a lie told to her entire department in order to tell the killer a deeper truth: she was coming for him.

The drive back to the station felt like a journey to a parallel world. Leaving the quiet, malevolent order of Croft’s workshop for the controlled chaos of the incident room was a jarring transition. Astor moved through it like a phantom, her body present but her mind already in the misty fields of the water meadows. She briefed Chief Inspector Davies with a performance of cool, deductive brilliance, laying out the evidence against Croft in a narrative so compelling and logical that it left no room for questions. She presented the profile of a "narcissistic artisan," a killer obsessed with creating a legacy, and skillfully guided Davies towards the conclusion she needed him to reach.

"He's referencing wind, sir. Kites," she explained, gesturing to the whiteboard where the words from the book were now transcribed. Her gaze fell on the glove compartment of her car. The fierce, unsmiling girl in the photograph was in there, safe and silent, a relic from a battle no one else knew had been fought. The hunt was over, the crusade was won. But as she sat there in the quiet of her car, the silence pressing in, she understood with a chilling certainty that the war—the one against the quiet, the memory, and the long, empty road that stretched out before her—had only just begun.

The silence in her flat was a physical presence, heavier than the waterlogged blanket she had discarded by the door. She stood under the scalding spray of the shower for a long time, trying to steam the river’s memory from her skin, but the cold was deeper now, a part of her cellular structure. When she finally stepped out, wrapped in a towel, she avoided her own reflection in the fogged-up mirror. She did not want to see the eyes that had looked into Julian Croft’s and recognized the dark shape of his logic, even while despising it. On her forearm, the thin, red line where his needle had grazed her was a stark and intimate signature, a brand marking the boundary he had crossed, and the one she had been forced to defend. Sleep, when it finally came, was not a refuge. It was a blank, bottomless void, a silence so absolute it was more terrifying than any nightmare.

The following morning, the police station hummed with the low-grade, triumphant energy of a problem solved. The air, which for months had been thick with the metallic tang of fear and caffeine, now smelled of relief and paperwork. The Goblin case was being dismantled, its gruesome components filed away into neat, labelled boxes. Astor walked through the bullpen and felt a profound sense of dislocation, as if she were a ghost haunting the scene of her own life. People nodded to her, their expressions a mixture of awe and a faint, nervous deference. She was no longer just their sergeant. She was the woman who had gone into the river with the monster and come out alone. They looked at her not as a colleague, but as a relic from a battle they were glad they had only read about.

Her own office felt small and suffocating. On her desk, a new pile of files awaited, a testament to the world’s relentless mundanity. A dispute over a fence line. Vandalism at the bus station. A stolen bicycle. She stared at the top file, its cheerful blue folder an obscenity, and felt nothing. Corbin appeared in the doorway, his presence a familiar, rumpled anchor in the strange new current of her life. He didn’t speak, just placed a steaming mug on the corner of her desk and looked at her, his gaze missing nothing. He saw the new stillness in her, the way she held her shoulders as if bracing for a blow that had already landed.

“The official report is a masterpiece of creative nonfiction,” he said quietly, leaning against the doorframe. “According to Davies, a textbook execution of a high-risk takedown, all units performing flawlessly under his strategic command. You get a pat on the back for 'tenacious investigative work'.” He paused, letting the bitter absurdity of it hang in the air. “I read your supplemental, the one that won’t see the light of day. The real one.” He looked at her arm, where a small bandage now covered the graze. “You had to become a bigger monster than he was, didn’t you? Down there in the dark. That’s how you won.” It was not an accusation. It was a diagnosis, delivered with the grim affection of a man who had seen too much to be shocked by anything, but could still be worried for a friend.

Astor looked down at her hands, wrapped around the warm mug. “He wanted to write the ending,” she said, her voice low and rough. “I couldn’t let him.” Corbin nodded slowly. “I know. Just… when you go that deep into the dark to win, it can be hard to remember the way back to the light.” He pushed himself away from the door, his duty as her unofficial conscience discharged. “Don’t let him have any part of you, Astor. Not one word.” But she feared it was already too late. She had understood Croft’s poisonous poetry, and that understanding was a stain the river could not wash away. The silence of her old ghosts was not peace; it was the empty space they had left for this new one to occupy.

Later that day, a memo arrived on her desk through the internal mail system, a single sheet of paper in a crisp manila envelope. It was a formal request from the National Crime Agency’s Behavioural Analysis Unit. They were requesting the temporary transfer of evidence item #734 from the Croft case: the leather-bound journal. The request stated their intention to study the subject’s “highly organized linguistic and ritualistic structures” as a potential tool for profiling future offenders. Her victory in the interrogation room, her pronouncement that his work would be forgotten, turned to ash in her mouth. She had told him his book would rot, unread, in a vault. Instead, it was going to be studied, its hateful, elegant script pored over by academics and profilers. Julian Croft, the artist, was going to get his audience after all. The world, in its endless, pragmatic hunger, would find a use for his poison. She dropped the memo onto her desk, the single sheet of paper landing with the weight of a tombstone. She looked at the blue folder, the one about the stolen bicycle, its mundane reality a distant, unreachable shore. Corbin was wrong. The fight wasn't over. It had simply changed its shape, moving from the dark river into the quiet, brightly lit corridors of her own mind.

The paper felt flimsy in her hand, utterly disproportionate to the weight of its message. Astor read the memo from the NCA a second time, then a third, as if the words might rearrange themselves into a different, less sickening configuration. They did not. *Highly organized linguistic and ritualistic structures.* They were going to make a science out of his filth. They would dissect his poison, name its components, and add it to their library of human depravity. The image of academics in sterile seminar rooms discussing Croft's "luminous" ink and "archaic cadence" rose in her mind, a vision of a future she had promised him would never exist. Her victory in the interrogation room, the one clean, sharp blow she had landed, was a lie. He would not be forgotten. He would be footnoted. His evil, far from being erased, was being given a catalogue number and a place in the canon of monsters.

She let the memo fall and reached for the blue folder on top of the pile. *RE: THEFT OF BICYCLE (RALEIGH CHOPPER, ORANGE).* The words swam before her eyes, nonsensical and trivial. She tried to focus, to force her mind back into the familiar grooves of professional duty. A boy's prized possession, stolen from his garden shed. There was a victim here, a small, tangible injustice that needed addressing. But her mind refused to engage. How could she invest herself in the hunt for a stolen bicycle when she had just spent months hunting a man who stole heartbeats? The scale of it felt absurd, a cosmic joke. The language of the report—the neat boxes for victim's name, perpetrator's description, method of entry—seemed like a child’s game compared to the dense, spidery script she had committed to memory. She was a detective, but the very nature of crime now seemed bifurcated into the banal and the mythic, and she felt capable of investigating neither.

The drive home was a blur. She found herself parked by the water meadows, the engine off, the windows up. The evening was drawing in, casting long, skeletal shadows from the trees. The river flowed past, a dark, indifferent presence. She did not feel the pull to get out, to walk the bank. The ground there was now forever marked, a stage she had no desire to revisit. The car, once just a tool, had become a hermetic seal, a thin layer of steel and glass separating her from a world that no longer made sense. Her hand drifted towards the glove compartment, her fingers tracing its outline. The photograph was in there, a relic from another time, another Astor. Looking at that fierce, unbroken girl now would feel like an act of cruelty. That girl believed in clean wins and just rewards. What could this new Astor, this woman who had promised a monster oblivion only to become the facilitator of his legacy, possibly say to her? She let her hand drop back into her lap.

The silence in her flat was not empty; it was full of the things she was trying not to think about. She bypassed the living room, the kitchen, and went straight to the small, cheap desk in the corner of her bedroom where she sometimes finished paperwork. The swimming medals on the wall seemed to watch her, their metallic sheen dull in the fading light. They were trophies from a simpler war, a contest against the clock and the current. This new war was against ambiguity, against the slow, creeping horror that nothing was ever truly finished, that evil was not a thing to be vanquished but a resource to be managed. She pulled the NCA memo from her bag, smoothed its creases on the desk, and filled out the accompanying transfer authorisation form. Her signature, usually a sharp, decisive slash of ink, was slow and laboured. With each letter of her name, she felt as though she were signing not a bureaucratic form, but a confession of failure. Evidence #734 was now cleared for travel. She had kept her professional promise, and in doing so, had broken the most important one she had ever made to herself.

Days bled into a week, and Astor moved through her life like a tourist. She answered questions, she filed reports, she interviewed the owner of the stolen bicycle with a detached professionalism that felt like a costume. The silence that Corbin had warned her about was a constant, low hum in her ears, the sound of an engine that has been switched off but is still radiating heat. Her morning swims became a grim duty rather than a release. The cold of the river Milt no longer felt like a baptism, a scouring of the soul. It now felt like an accusation. Every stroke was a reminder of the struggle, every lungful of frigid air a memory of Croft's gurgling terror. The water didn't wash anything away anymore; it simply reflected the stain that was already there. She found herself cutting the swims short, driven from the water not by the cold, but by the oppressive weight of the memories it held.

It was Corbin who finally breached the perimeter of her isolation. He found her staring out the window of the station's bleak canteen, a cup of untouched tea cooling in her hands. He didn’t sit, just stood beside her, following her gaze to the huddled grey roofs of Milton. “You look like you’re a thousand miles away, Sergeant,” he said, his voice quiet. “Or a thousand years. I can’t tell which.” She didn’t turn, her reflection a pale, indistinct smudge on the grimy glass. “It’s just… quiet,” she replied, the same answer she had given him before, but the words felt even more hollow now. “Too quiet. It feels like waiting for the other shoe to drop.” Corbin grunted, a sound of grim understanding. “There is no other shoe, Astor. That’s the problem. The storm’s passed. This is just the weather. You have to learn to live in it again.”

He slid a new file onto the table beside her, its pristine cover a stark contrast to the old, dog-eared case files of the Goblin investigation. “Davies wants you to take a look at this. A walk-in. Young woman came in this morning, says her brother’s missing.” Astor’s entire body went rigid. The word 'missing' was a key turning in a lock she had tried so hard to seal. She wanted to refuse, to push the file away, to tell him to give it to someone else, anyone else. The thought of walking back into that particular darkness, the one filled with frantic relatives and the slow, ticking clock of fading hope, was physically nauseating. She had just crawled out of that pit; she had no desire to be lowered back in. “Give it to Peters,” she said, her voice flat. “It’s a good starter case for him.”

“It’s not a starter case,” Corbin replied, his tone brooking no argument. He tapped the file. “The brother is a student at the university. An art student. Specializing in sculpture and mixed-media installations. He was last seen three days ago by his flatmate. He left a note.” Astor finally turned her head, a cold dread coiling in her stomach. “What kind of note?” Corbin’s eyes were dark, his cynical mask firmly back in place, a shield against what he was about to say. “It’s not a suicide note. It’s more of a… mission statement. All about finding the ‘hidden beauty in urban decay’ and creating a ‘masterpiece of sublime transformation’.” He let the words hang in the air, a deliberate, unavoidable echo of a voice she was desperately trying to forget. “The sister’s worried because he was obsessed with the Goblin case. Followed every detail. She said he called Croft ‘a true artist, misunderstood by the prosaic world’.”

## Chapter 7

For a long moment, the canteen ceased to exist. The clatter of cutlery, the low murmur of conversation, the smell of burnt toast—it all receded into a distant, muffled roar. The only thing in focus was the file, its clean edges a stark frame around a new abyss that had just opened at Astor’s feet. Corbin’s words were not just information; they were an incantation, conjuring the ghost she had just buried. *A true artist, misunderstood.* The phrase, so full of pathetic, second-hand romanticism, was a direct echo from the black heart of Croft’s philosophy. It was a germ that had escaped the quarantine of his workshop and found a new host. The silence she had been living in was not an ending. It was a caesura, a pause before the theme repeated in a minor, uglier key.

Her first instinct was a violent, visceral rejection. She had earned her peace, paid for it in the currency of her own soul down in the cold, dark water of the Milt. She had done her part. This foul echo, this pathetic sequel, was not her responsibility. But as she looked at Corbin, she saw the grim certainty in his eyes. He had not brought this to her out of cruelty. He had brought it to her because she was the only one inoculated, the only one who had developed an antibody to this specific strain of beautiful, hateful poison. She was the world’s sole, unwilling expert on the artistic sensibilities of Julian Croft. To give this to Peters would be an act of malpractice, like sending a rookie to disarm a bomb with a manual written in a dead language only she could read. With a slow, leaden movement that felt like a surrender, she reached out and pulled the file towards her.

The interview with the sister, a young woman named Clara, was a harrowing exercise in déjà vu. She sat in the sterile interview room, twisting a damp tissue in her hands, her face a mask of terror, confusion, and a deep, gnawing shame. She spoke of her brother, Leo, in the fractured, bewildered tones of someone trying to describe a stranger who happened to share her childhood. He had always been quiet, artistic, a little morbid. But after the Goblin case broke, something had shifted. He became secretive, his art grew darker, and his conversations became peppered with philosophical jargon about 'liminality' and 'aesthetic transformation' that he had clearly gleaned from secondhand sources. He had wallpapered his room with newspaper clippings about Croft, not as a study of a killer, but as a fan collecting memorabilia of an idol.

Leo’s room was a pathetic parody of Croft’s workshop. Where Croft’s lair had been a testament to disciplined, meticulous craftsmanship, Leo’s student flat was a chaotic mess of pretentious squalor. The air smelled of turpentine, stale cigarette smoke, and damp plaster. Instead of anatomical charts, there were posters of bleak, industrial photography. Instead of elegant, hand-bound books, there were stacks of cheap paperbacks on philosophy and gothic literature, their spines broken, their pages dog-eared. And his art. Astor stood before a large canvas on which he had glued dead pigeons, bits of broken bottles, and rusted metal shards into a crude, ugly collage. It was a desperate attempt to replicate Croft’s aesthetic of decay, but it lacked any of the chilling precision. It was simply a mess. It was the work of a boy trying on a man’s evil like an ill-fitting coat.

The note, left on his unmade bed, confirmed it. It was a three-page, rambling manifesto, a torrent of plagiarised ideas and adolescent angst. He wrote of Milton as a "carcass of industry" and his intention to "reveal its latent beauty" through a "final, transformative act." He spoke of a "dialogue with the master," an intention to create a piece that would be an answer to Croft’s work, a new chapter in the book that Astor had promised would remain closed. The revulsion that filled her was profound, but it was different from the cold dread Croft had inspired. This was not the work of a lucid, predatory monster. This was the work of a lost, impressionable, and deeply dangerous young man who had mistaken a psychopath for a prophet. He was not a goblin from a forgotten fairy tale. He was the first acolyte of a new and terrible church.

She took a photograph of the note and the collage back to the station, the images feeling like a contamination in her pocket. She pinned them to the freshly cleaned whiteboard in the incident room, the pristine white surface a jarring backdrop for Leo’s ugly art. Corbin stood beside her, his arms crossed, his face grim. “A fan club with a membership of one,” he muttered. “So, where does a wannabe artist go to create his masterpiece of sublime transformation?” Astor stared at the photograph of the collage, at the dead birds and broken glass, at the desperate attempt to find meaning in ruin. He wouldn't create something new. He was a copycat, a commentator. He would go to a place that already held the meaning he was trying to emulate. A place that was already a part of the story.

“He’s not after a person,” Astor said, the realisation solidifying in her mind. “Not yet. His note, it’s all about place. Urban decay. The carcass of industry.” Her mind flashed back to the first morning, to her swim in the river, to the landmarks she passed. The water meadows were a place of life, of summer kites. The park was for children. The war memorial was a place of honour. None of them fit. “The old wool mill,” she said, her voice sharp with certainty. “The husk of broken windows and nesting pigeons. It’s a ruin. It’s a monument to the decay he’s worshipping. And it’s isolated. He’s going to make his installation there. He’s creating a shrine.” The hunt was on again, but the feeling was utterly different. This was not a crusade against a mythic evil. This was a grim and necessary intervention, a desperate attempt to stop a foolish boy from turning himself into a monster in a pathetic bid to impress a dead man’s ghost.

The order, when it came, was devoid of the desperate, high-stakes urgency that had defined the Croft investigation. There was no personal crusade in Astor’s voice, only the flat, clipped authority of a professional dealing with a hazardous spill. “Corbin, get a tactical team ready. Two vehicles, soft approach. I want silent containment, not a cavalry charge. Peters, you’re with me. Pull the original architectural plans for the mill. I want to know every entrance and every weak point before we’re even on site.” The room, which had fallen into a watchful silence, snapped back into a low hum of activity. This was a familiar rhythm, the comfortable procedure of a standard police operation. But for Astor, it felt like being forced to walk back into a contaminated zone she had just barely escaped, her flimsy hazmat suit already compromised.

The drive to the industrial outskirts of Milton was a journey through a landscape of neglect. They passed boarded-up warehouses and rusting chain-link fences, the forgotten bones of the town’s industrial past. Astor sat in the passenger seat of the lead car, staring out at the decay, seeing it not as urban blight but as a breeding ground. Croft’s evil had not been a singular, contained event; it was a spore that had been released into the air, and it had found fertile ground in the romanticised decay of a place like this, in the mind of a boy like Leo. She felt a profound, weary anger, not at the misguided art student, but at Croft himself. His true, final crime was not the murders, but the creation of a story so seductive it had inspired others to follow him into the dark.

The old wool mill loomed against the grey sky, a red-brick tombstone for a dead industry. Its sheer size was intimidating, a labyrinth of broken floors and rotting infrastructure. The air hung thick with the smell of damp brick, pigeon droppings, and the metallic ghost of lanolin. Following the century-old plans, they made their entrance through a collapsed section of wall in a rear loading bay, the crunch of broken glass under their boots the only sound. Inside, the mill was a cathedral of decay. Vast, cathedral-like windows, their panes shattered, cast long, dusty shafts of afternoon light across the main floor, illuminating the hulking, silent shapes of long-dead machinery. The rhythmic cooing of hundreds of pigeons from the high rafters provided a constant, unsettling chorus. There was a faint glimmer of a single, unsteady light from a distant corner of the cavernous space, a lone firefly in a vast, dark cavern.

They followed the light, moving with a practiced silence between the skeletal remains of spinning mules and carding engines. The glow led them to a cleared space on the upper floor, where the old foreman’s office had once stood. There, in the center of the floor, illuminated by a single, bare work-light dangling from an extension cord, was Leo. He had his back to them, utterly absorbed in his work. He had constructed a grotesque tableau. Three child-sized mannequins, likely stolen from a defunct department store, were arranged in attitudes of repose around a rusted iron boiler. They were draped in filthy, decaying cloth, and Leo was painstakingly painting on their plastic limbs with a dark, reddish-brown fluid. He was humming, a tuneless, discordant sound that echoed slightly in the vast space. Astor’s stomach tightened into a cold, hard knot. It was a pathetic, horrifying mimicry, a cargo-cult imitation of a master’s ritual. He was creating a shrine to a murderer, using the language of a crime he did not have the courage or the conviction to commit himself. Astor held up a hand, signalling the tactical officers to hold their positions in the shadows. This was not a breach-and-clear situation. She stepped out of the darkness and into the weak circle of light, her shadow falling over his profane creation.

The humming stopped. For a moment, Leo remained frozen, a paintbrush laden with the dark red fluid held aloft. He turned his head slowly, his movements stiff, like one of the mannequins he was tending. His face, when he finally revealed it, was shockingly young, barely out of his teens, with a smudge of dirt on his cheek and feverishly bright eyes. A flicker of surprise crossed his features, which was then immediately replaced by a slow, dawning smile of beatific recognition. He did not see a police officer. He saw a key player from the drama that had consumed him, a celebrity from the pantheon of his dark obsession. In his deluded mind, her appearance was not an intrusion; it was a validation, the arrival of the one critic whose opinion truly mattered.

"Sergeant Astor," he breathed, his voice filled with an unnerving, reverent awe. He gestured with the paintbrush towards his grotesque tableau, a museum curator presenting his prize exhibit. "You came. I knew you would. I knew someone would have to bear witness. Only you could truly appreciate the resonance, the… the dialogue I’m having. This is my answer to his work. Where he collected the silence of the living, I am gathering the echoes from the dead. This place, it speaks. I am simply giving it a voice."

Astor took another step forward, the sound of her boot on the gritty floor a sharp, declarative sound that cut through his pretentious monologue. Her face was a granite mask of weary disgust. She felt no fear, only a profound, soul-crushing exhaustion. This boy, with his secondhand philosophy and his pathetic, derivative art, was the living embodiment of her failure. "There is no dialogue, Leo," she said, her voice flat and cold, utterly devoid of the emotion he craved. "You're not having a conversation. You're just talking to yourself in a ruined building. This isn't art. It's vandalism with a thesaurus. And it's over."

The smile vanished from Leo’s face, replaced by a flash of petulant, wounded indignation. He had been expecting admiration, or at least a debate on the merits of his work. Her blunt, dismissive pragmatism was an insult he could not process. "You don't understand," he stammered, his voice rising. "How can you not understand? You were there! At the river! You touched his final masterpiece. You were the final page! He chose you! You, of all people, should see what I am doing here is a continuation, an evolution! I am taking the next step! He was the text; I am the commentary!"

Astor let out a short, sharp sound that was almost a laugh, but it held no humour. It was the sound of a spring breaking. "The next step? The 'text', as you call him, spent his last moments screaming and choking on river water, his face blue with terror. His 'masterpiece', as you see it, is evidence item #734. It's going to be picked apart by behavioural analysts until there's nothing left but dry data. He wasn't a master, Leo. He was a sick, lonely man who got his power from hurting things smaller than him. And you," she said, her voice dropping to a low, merciless quiet, "you're just a sad little boy who read his diary and thought it was scripture. There is no evolution. There is only a disease, and you have mistaken its symptoms for a state of grace."

That was the truth he could not bear. The utter de-sanctification of his idol, the reduction of his grand, romantic quest to a mere pathology. A strangled cry of pure, childish rage tore from his throat. He was not a cold, precise killer. He was a fanboy whose hero had just been comprehensively debunked. With a howl of fury, he lunged, not at her, but at his materials. He grabbed a can of the reddish-brown paint and flung it, the thick liquid arcing through the air. His intent was not to harm her, but to mark her, to make her a part of his defiled creation, to force her into his narrative. Astor didn't even flinch. She simply took a half-step to the side, and the paint splattered against the brick wall behind her, a meaningless, ugly smear.

The gesture was all she needed. She gave a small, almost imperceptible nod of her head. From the deep shadows surrounding the circle of light, the darkness detached itself and took form. The tactical team moved with a swift, silent, and brutal economy of motion. Before Leo could even register their presence, two officers had him, pinning his arms behind his back, their movements impersonal and absolute. He thrashed wildly, screaming, not curses or threats, but a torrent of incoherent, philosophical jargon, a desperate last attempt to assert the reality of a world that was dissolving around him. A third officer kicked the extension cord, and the single dangling bulb went dark, plunging the tableau into shadow. A moment later, the powerful beams of several tactical flashlights sliced through the gloom, their harsh, white light stripping the scene of all its manufactured atmosphere, revealing it for what it was: a pile of junk and stolen mannequins in a dirty, derelict building. As they forced him to his knees, his screams turned to sobbing, the heartbroken wails of a true believer whose god had just been revealed as a cheap, plastic doll.

## Chapter 8

There was no catharsis in the aftermath, only a grubby sense of finality. The tactical team worked with an impersonal efficiency, their movements devoid of the high-stakes tension that had charged the air at Croft’s tannery. Leo’s sobbing subsided into a pathetic, hiccuping whimper as they secured him in flex-cuffs. He was just a boy, overwhelmed and out of his depth, a child playing dress-up in a monster’s clothes. Astor watched them lead him away, his shoulders slumped in defeat, and felt nothing akin to victory. This was not the culmination of a hunt. It was a custodial matter, like clearing a squatter from a condemned building. The ugly tableau of mannequins and paint, stripped of its theatrical lighting and its creator's manic energy, was just a pile of rubbish, a sad testament to a profound and dangerous foolishness.

The drive back to the station was a study in silence. Peters sat in the driver’s seat, his knuckles white on the steering wheel, his gaze fixed on the road ahead. He was wrestling with what he had seen, the raw, unvarnished delusion of a mind infected by another’s evil. He wanted to say something, Astor knew, to offer a platitude about a job well done or a crisis averted. But he wisely kept his counsel, sensing that any such remark would be a profanity in the heavy, exhausted atmosphere that filled the car. Astor stared out the passenger window, watching the familiar streets of Milton slide past, but seeing them with new eyes. She saw the cracks in the pavement, the graffiti on the walls, the forgotten corners and derelict spaces, and saw them not as urban decay, but as potential altars, fallow ground waiting for a new seed of madness to take root. She had not ended something by capturing Croft; she had merely curated his legacy, making him infamous enough to beget this new, uglier strain of disciple.

Corbin was waiting for them in the empty incident room, a single file open on the otherwise clean expanse of the central table. He didn't ask how it went; the answer was written in the weary slump of Astor's shoulders. He simply pushed a fresh mug of tea towards her empty chair. "Clara’s been informed. "This whole thing… it was a performance for an audience of one. For me. He needed me to validate his work, to see him as a successor. He needed to be part of the story." The bitter truth of it sat between them, a cold and unpalatable meal. She was no longer just a detective. She was the unwilling high priestess of a cult, the only one who could recognize and interpret the grotesque scripture its founder had left behind.

The call came the next morning. It was not from Davies or anyone within their own constabulary. The voice on the other end was smooth, polished, and carried the detached, intellectual curiosity of a lepidopterist discussing a rare specimen. "Sergeant Astor?
