"I'll have to see my schedule, Doctor," she said, her voice a flat, noncommittal wall of professionalism. She ended the call without waiting for his reply and stood for a long time, staring at the grey slate roofs of the town. Corbin had been right. This was the new weather. The world would not let her forget. It would not let her heal. It had found a use for her scars.

That evening, she did not go for a swim. The thought of the river was unbearable. Instead, she drove out of town, to the small, windswept car park overlooking the sea, a place she hadn't visited in years. The wind whipped off the grey water, cold and clean, smelling of salt and distance. It was a different kind of cold from the river's, less personal, less intimate. She finally opened the glove compartment and took out the photograph of the ten-year-old girl with the swimming medal. She looked at the fierce, proud child, at the unsmiling, determined set of her jaw. For weeks, looking at this photo had felt like an act of self-recrimination. But now, something had shifted. She was not looking at her past self. She was looking at a different person entirely, a girl whose world was governed by lane lines and stopwatches, a world of clean, simple contests. That girl was a stranger. And she deserved to rest. She could not be asked to fight this new, dirtier war of echoes and ideas.

Astor did not put the photograph back in the glove compartment. She took it back to her flat and found an old, sturdy shoebox in the back of her wardrobe, a box filled with forgotten things—old report cards, a few letters, a dried corsage from a police ball she'd been forced to attend. She placed the silver frame gently inside, on top of the other relics of a life that was no longer hers. She put the lid on the box and pushed it back into the darkness of the closet. It was not an act of forgetting. It was an act of preservation, of placing that innocent, fierce-eyed girl into protective custody, where the fallout from this new war could not reach her. Then she walked to her desk. She took out a new, empty notebook and a pen. She opened it to the first page. At the top, she wrote a name: Dr. Alistair Thorne. Underneath it, she wrote: *NCA, Behavioural Analysis.* She drew a box around it. This was not a case file. It was a battle plan. If the world was determined to make her an expert on this disease, then she would become a hunter of its every symptom, its every carrier, its every academic apologist. The crusade was not over. It had just gone cold.

The notebook was cheap, its pages thin and thirsty for ink. Astor wrote with a deliberate, almost architectural precision, her handwriting stripped of all flourishes. The names and acronyms she inscribed were not clues in a murder investigation; they were strategic targets. *Dr. Alistair Thorne. NCA Behavioural Analysis. Ideological Transmission. Performative Homicide.* Each phrase was a brick in a new wall she was building around herself, a fortress of cold, hard intellect. The paperwork for the Leo case sat in a neglected pile, its forms and procedures feeling like artifacts from a simpler, more honest time. That case had been about stopping an action. This new, undeclared war was about containing a thought, a much more insidious and difficult enemy to fight. Her small flat, once a spartan refuge, was transforming into an intelligence cell, its sole occupant a woman who had traded her ghosts for a single, all-consuming obsession.

The change was not lost on her colleagues. At the station, she moved with a new, unsettling economy, her focus narrowed to a pinprick. She delegated ruthlessly, handing off the routine burglaries and domestic disputes that were the lifeblood of precinct work with an impatient disinterest that bordered on contempt. She was a surgeon who had just performed a heart transplant being asked to put a plaster on a scraped knee, and her lack of enthusiasm was a palpable frost in the air. Even Peters, who still viewed her with a kind of hero-worship, began to approach her desk with a hesitant caution, as if the ground around it were unstable. The gap between Sergeant Astor the police officer and Astor the unwilling specialist was widening into a chasm, and she was making no effort to bridge it.

Corbin watched it all from his usual position, leaning in a doorway, his coffee cup a permanent fixture in his hand. He waited for a week, a silent observer charting the tidal pull of her retreat from the world. He finally cornered her in the station’s small, under-utilised library, where she was poring over a thick, academic text on forensic psychology. "You haven't been to the river, Astor," he stated, the observation landing with the force of an accusation. He gestured with his mug towards the book she was reading. "You’ve traded one obsession for another. Drowning yourself in cold water, or drowning yourself in cold print. It’s the same thing. You’re just trying to find a place so deep the ghosts can’t follow." Astor didn't look up from the page, though her reading had stopped. "There are no ghosts anymore, Miles," she said, her voice quiet. "Just a contagion. And this is the only way I know how to study the disease." He shook his head slowly, a sad, knowing look on his face. "Be careful you don’t become a carrier."

Ignoring Corbin’s warning, or perhaps because of it, she made the call. She dialled the number for the National Crime Agency from a sterile interview room, choosing the impersonal space over her own office. When Thorne answered, his voice was just as she remembered: smooth, articulate, and radiating a placid, academic confidence. "Sergeant Astor. I was hoping I'd hear from you," he began, a note of satisfaction in his tone. "I trust you've considered my proposal." Astor bypassed the pleasantries, her own voice a stark, functional counterpoint to his polished warmth. "I am a serving police officer, Doctor. If my commanding officer authorises a consultation as part of an official investigation, I will comply with my duty. I am not a freelance academic. My insights, as you call them, belong to this department. If the NCA wants them, they can make a formal request through the proper channels."

There was a moment of surprised silence on the other end of the line. She had just taken his flattering invitation and reframed it as a bureaucratic chore, stripping it of all its personal, psychological weight. She was refusing to be his specimen. Thorne recovered quickly, his chuckle a smooth, practiced sound. "Of course, Sergeant. Forgive my informal approach. We're all on the same side, after all. Consider the formal request on its way. We'd like you to come down to our facility near Quantico. A preliminary visit. Walk us through your experience with both Croft and the copycat. A change of scenery might do you good." The offer was a lure, dressed up as a professional courtesy. He was inviting her into the heart of his intellectual fortress. For a moment, she hesitated, the thought of leaving Milton, of leaving the river and the town she had bled for, a jarring dislocation. But this was the front line of the new war. It was not in a derelict mill or on a misty riverbank. It was in a quiet, climate-controlled room with men like Thorne. "I'll await my orders, Doctor," she said, and ended the call. She sat back in the hard plastic chair, the silence of the interview room pressing in. She had accepted the invitation. She was going into the lion's den, not as prey, but as a hunter with a new and terrible field of expertise.

## Chapter 9

The official orders from Davies were a masterpiece of bureaucratic detachment. They arrived in a crisp internal envelope, authorising a temporary secondment to the National Crime Agency for "inter-departmental consultation on a closed case." The language was sterile, clinical, and offered Sergeant Astor a clean, administrative escape route from the oppressive quiet of her new life. Davies, she knew, would be delighted. He was loaning out his problematic, brooding detective to a more prestigious department, a magnanimous gesture that cost him nothing and temporarily removed a subordinate whose very presence was a reminder of a story he could not fully control. Astor read the memo without expression, folded it once, and placed it in the inner pocket of her jacket. It was not a reprieve. It was a deployment. That night, she packed a small, functional holdall with two changes of clothes, a toothbrush, and the new, empty notebook. She packed no mementos, no photographs, no ghosts.

The morning she left, she broke a ritual by not even looking in the direction of the river. She drove straight to the station car park, the rising sun a pale, indifferent smear in her rear-view mirror. Corbin was there, leaning against the bonnet of his own battered Ford, a mug of what was certainly terrible coffee held in his hands like a sacrament. He didn't offer her any. He just watched as she threw her holdall onto the back seat of her car. He had seen the orders, of course. Nothing of consequence happened in the station without passing through the filter of his weary omniscience.

"Don't let them put you under glass, Astor," he said, his voice a low rumble. "These national guys, they're collectors. They'll listen to your story, thank you for it, then stick a pin through it and add it to their collection. They're no different from Croft, they just use PowerPoint instead of blood." His cynicism was a shield, but beneath it lay a genuine, paternal fear for her. He was watching the last vestiges of the woman he knew pack a bag and drive toward a place from which she might not, in any meaningful sense, return.

"They can try," Astor replied, the two words a vow of resistance. She got into the car, the engine turning over with a familiar, healthy cough. She looked at Corbin through the open window, at his rumpled suit and his tired, knowing eyes, and felt a sudden, sharp pang of something she could not name. He was her last anchor to the grimy, solid reality of police work, of stolen bicycles and pub fights. The world she was driving toward was one of ideas, of theories, a place of smoke and mirrors. With a final, brief nod that was both a farewell and a promise, she pulled out of the car park and left the huddled grey roofs of Milton behind.

The NCA facility was not in Quantico, but in a sprawling, anonymous campus of smoked glass and manicured lawns carved out of the English countryside, a place that prided itself on having no history. Milton was a town of old brick, river rot, and memory; this place was an exercise in forgetting. The air inside was cool and recycled, the corridors silent save for the faint, electronic beep of keycard readers. There were no dusty archive boxes here, only gleaming server racks humming behind reinforced glass. It was a sterile, climate-controlled environment where the messiness of human evil was processed into neat, digestible data points. It was the architectural embodiment of Dr. Alistair Thorne.

He met her in the expansive, minimalist lobby, a space designed to impress and intimidate with its sheer emptiness. He was exactly as his voice had suggested: tall, with a lean, confident posture, wearing a soft, grey tweed jacket over a crisp, open-necked shirt. His salt-and-pepper beard was neatly trimmed, and his eyes, a sharp, intelligent blue, held a look of frank, undisguised curiosity. He was assessing her, the primary exhibit, with the practiced eye of a connoisseur. "Sergeant Astor. A pleasure to finally meet you in person," he said, extending a hand. His grip was firm, dry, and brief. "Thank you for coming. We have a great deal to discuss. I hope the journey wasn't too arduous."

He led her on what he called a "brief tour," a choreographed walk through his domain. They passed rooms where analysts sat before vast, multi-screen displays, tracking the digital footprints of organised crime syndicates and mapping terrorist networks. Thorne spoke in a fluid stream of acronyms and jargon, explaining their methodologies of predictive analysis and psychological profiling with an air of effortless mastery. He was showing her the sheer scale and sophistication of his world, a subtle act of intellectual dominance. Astor walked beside him in silence, her expression unreadable, her mind a cold, efficient recording device. She was not a tourist. She was a reconnaissance soldier mapping enemy territory.

Finally, he led her to a smaller, more private room at the end of a secure corridor. It was a corner office with a panoramic window overlooking a sterile, geometric garden. It was his personal study. And in the center of the room, on a polished mahogany table, positioned under a precise, museum-quality spotlight, was evidence item #734. Croft's book. It lay open, not in a plastic evidence bag, but resting on a custom-made velvet stand, its dark leather and cream-coloured pages presented with the reverence usually reserved for a national treasure. "The ur-text," Thorne said, his voice soft with satisfaction, echoing Corbin's cynical prediction. "The genesis of the narrative. Beautiful, isn't it? In its own terrible way."

He gestured for her to sit in one of two severe leather armchairs, and with a small, theatrical flourish, activated a recording device on the table. "Now, Sergeant," he began, his tone shifting from tour guide to inquisitor, "I'd like to begin, if I may, not with the physical evidence, but with the subjective experience. Tell me about the moment you first felt a direct, personal connection to the subject. The moment the story ceased to be a case file and became a… dialogue. Let's talk about the river. Not as a location, but as a symbolic space."

Astor met his gaze, her own eyes like chips of flint. She ignored the comfortable chair and remained standing, a subtle refusal to settle into his curated environment. "The Milt is a third-order river with an average flow rate of 12 cubic metres per second," she said, her voice a flat, factual counterpoint to his lyrical prompt. "In February, its average temperature is 4.3 degrees Celsius. Unprotected immersion leads to loss of fine motor control in under ten minutes and unconsciousness in under an hour. It is a location, Doctor. Not a symbol."

Thorne’s smile didn’t falter; if anything, it widened, a flicker of genuine delight in his eyes. He appreciated her resistance; it made the specimen more interesting. "Excellent. A baseline of empirical fact. I like that," he said smoothly. "But the subject didn't choose it for its flow rate, did he? He chose it for you. And now, it seems others are choosing to write about it, too." He turned to a large monitor on his desk and, with a few clicks of his mouse, brought up a web page. It was a forum, its design stark and minimalist, dedicated to what it called 'Post-Forensic Art'. The page was filled with posts dissecting the Milton Goblin case, users arguing about Croft’s 'methodology' and 'aesthetic choices' with the fervour of film students debating a difficult director.

Thorne pointed to one particular thread. "This is what I wanted to show you," he said, his voice losing a fraction of its placid confidence. "A new user appeared two days ago. They call themselves 'Epilogue'." On the screen was a block of text, written in a style that was a chillingly accurate mimicry of Croft’s, but with a different perspective. It was a lyrical, highly detailed description of the final struggle in the river, of the shock of the cold, the desperation of the fight, the final, gurgling scream. It was filled with small, intimate details—the feel of the current pulling them under, the glint of the needle before it was lost, the specific words Astor had spoken on the bank—details that had been in her confidential supplemental report and nowhere else. It was her experience, stolen, polished, and posted for public consumption. Thorne looked at her, his academic curiosity finally punctured by a sliver of genuine concern. "This user claims to be your collaborator. To be the one tasked with telling your side of the story. They say you wanted the world to know the 'terrible beauty' of what really happened." He leaned forward, his polished facade cracking just enough to reveal the sharp, analytical mind beneath. "Tell me, Sergeant. Who in your department had access to your sealed report?"

The words on the screen were a violation. A visceral, intimate theft that went deeper than Croft’s physical assault. He had tried to take her life; this anonymous author was stealing her memory, filching the most traumatic moments of her existence, polishing them like stolen jewels, and displaying them in a public square. The cold that flooded Astor’s veins was absolute, a cryogenic stasis that froze the air in her lungs. Every detail was there, stripped from the raw, unvarnished prose of her supplemental report and spun into a lyrical, grotesque imitation of Croft’s style. It was her pain, her fear, her brutal victory, repackaged as fan fiction for a ghoulish audience. For a moment, the pristine, climate-controlled office dissolved, and she was back in the churning, black water of the Milt, the weight of a dying man in her arms, the world a maelstrom of terror and adrenaline. And someone had been watching, taking notes.

Her mind, a machine trained to find the weak point in any system, instantly bypassed the emotional horror and began running a cold, brutal diagnostic. Her supplemental report had been sealed, flagged with the highest security classification available at the precinct level. It had never been digitised, existing only as a single hard copy, locked in the evidence vault. Physical access was required. The list of people with the clearance and the opportunity was terrifyingly, heartbreakingly short. Davies, as Chief Inspector, had the authority, but leaking secrets was anathema to a man obsessed with control and public perception. Peters, the rookie, had been a runner on the case, a gofer, but he would never have had unsupervised access to the vault. The thought was ludicrous. Which left only one name, a name so integral to her own professional sanity that her mind recoiled from it as if from a hot brand. Miles Corbin. He had the access. He had the trust. He had read the report in the pre-dawn chaos of the water meadows, his face a mask of grim understanding. The thought that he could be 'Epilogue', that his cynicism could curdle into this kind of profound, artistic betrayal, was a wound deeper than any Croft had inflicted.

Astor’s gaze lifted from the monitor and met Thorne’s. His eyes were bright, not with sympathy, but with the fervent, predatory excitement of a scientist who has just witnessed a new, unprecedented reaction in his petri dish. She refused to give him the satisfaction of seeing her crack. She marshalled her features into a mask of cold, professional indifference. “This is not a collaborator, Doctor,” she said, her voice a blade of ice. “This is a suspect in a criminal breach of a secure police network and theft of a classified document. This is not a dialogue. It is a felony.” She had taken his carefully constructed narrative framework and smashed it with the blunt, ugly hammer of the law. She was no longer his subject. She was a police officer, and this was now her crime scene.

The shift in her demeanor seemed only to delight Thorne further. He leaned back in his chair, a slow, appreciative smile spreading across his face. He was not insulted; he was impressed. “Of course, Sergeant. Forgive me. My academic lens tends to reframe everything as a text. But you must admit, the implications are fascinating. The narrative has metastasized. It’s no longer just Croft and his disciples; now we have a schism, a new voice emerging from within the ranks of the supposed righteous, claiming to speak for the antagonist. It suggests the story itself has a power that transcends its author, that it infects all who come into contact with it.” He steepled his fingers, his blue eyes gleaming. “This doesn’t change our work here, Sergeant. It enriches it. It adds a whole new layer of complexity to the ideological transmission we are studying.”

Astor felt a surge of pure, unadulterated fury, so cold and so intense it almost made her dizzy. He was talking about the theft of her soul as if it were a fascinating new plot twist. He wanted to keep her here, to study her reactions, to pin her to his corkboard and label her: *Antagonist, Exhibiting Signs of Narrative Infection.* She took a deliberate step back from the desk, creating a physical boundary between herself and his world of theories. "My work here is finished, Doctor," she announced, her voice flat and final. "This breach occurred within my jurisdiction. My presence is required at my home precinct to lead the internal investigation." She was pulling rank, using the language of her world to sever the connection to his. She was not a case study. She was the law, and she was going home to find the traitor who had put her most secret self on public display.

The long drive back to Milton was a journey through a landscape of ash. The trust that had been the bedrock of her professional life, the unspoken faith in the men and women who stood beside her, had been vaporized. Every car she passed, every face she glimpsed, was a potential enemy. The world, which had briefly seemed manageable after Leo's capture, was now revealed to be profoundly and fundamentally unsafe. The threat was no longer a monster in a ruined mill; it was a ghost in her own house, a smiling colleague who had read her deepest trauma and decided it would make a good story. As the familiar, huddled roofs of Milton appeared on the horizon, they no longer looked like home. They looked like the walls of a prison, and she knew, with a certainty that chilled her to the soul, that the traitor was waiting for her inside.

## Chapter 10

The Milton police station was an island of jarring normalcy in the storm of Astor’s mind. The familiar smell of stale coffee and disinfectant, the low hum of computer fans, the desultory chatter of officers finishing their shifts—it was all exactly as she had left it. But she had returned a different person, an antibody searching for a virus in its own host body. She walked through the bullpen with a fixed, unseeing gaze, ignoring the curious glances and hesitant greetings. Her focus was a singularity, a point of immense gravity that bent the world around it. She was not a sergeant returning to her desk. She was a hunter stepping onto a fresh trail, and the scent of betrayal was thick in the air.

She went directly to the evidence room, a cramped, windowless vault in the station’s basement. The clerk, a portly man named Henderson whose primary role in life was to guard against procedural errors, looked up from his crossword puzzle with mild surprise. Astor’s presence in his subterranean kingdom was rare, and her current intensity was a palpable force that made the dust motes in the air seem to vibrate. “I need to see the sign-in ledger for the Croft case,” she said, her voice devoid of pleasantry. “Specifically, the supplemental reports.”

Henderson, a creature of pure bureaucracy, blinked slowly. “They’re sealed, Sergeant. High security. Chief Inspector’s eyes only, post-archival.” Astor placed her hands flat on the high counter, her knuckles white. She leaned forward just enough to make her presence an immovable fact. “A section of my sealed, physical-copy-only report from that case has appeared online, Henderson. Which means ‘post-archival’ has been violated. I am opening an internal investigation into a security breach, effective immediately. Show me the ledger.” The color drained from Henderson’s face. A breach of his vault was not just a procedural error; it was a theological crisis. With trembling hands, he unlocked a heavy grey filing cabinet and produced a thick, leather-bound ledger, its pages filled with the neat columns and careful signatures that were the bedrock of his world.

She carried the ledger with her to Corbin’s office, the book feeling as heavy and damning as Croft’s had. She found him slumped in his chair, staring at a screen filled with budgetary spreadsheets, the Sisyphean task of every detective sergeant. She closed the door behind her, the soft click of the latch an unnaturally loud sound. He looked up, his weary eyes registering her presence, her intensity, the book in her hand. “You’re back early,” he said, his voice a low grumble. “Don’t tell me the national eggheads bored you to death already.”

“They had some interesting reading material,” Astor replied, her voice dangerously quiet. She placed the ledger on his desk, then slid a single sheet of paper, a printout of the ‘Epilogue’ post, on top of it. “My supplemental report. Word for word, in some places. Just with more adjectives. Someone read it, Miles. Someone who was there. Someone who had access.” She did not accuse him. She presented the evidence, the inexplicable fact of the betrayal, and waited. His reaction would be everything.

He read the first paragraph, his brow furrowed in confusion. He read the second, and his face slowly hardened, the cynical lines around his eyes deepening into cracks in a stone facade. By the time he finished, his expression was one of pure, venomous rage. He looked from the paper to her, then back to the paper, his mind clearly grappling with the sheer impossibility of the violation. “Who?” he finally snarled, the single word a jagged piece of glass. His fury was so genuine, so absolute, that it acted as a cleansing fire, instantly burning away the suspicion that had been poisoning Astor’s mind. This was not the reaction of a guilty man. This was the righteous anger of a trusted guardian whose charge had been violated. A profound, dizzying wave of relief washed over Astor, followed immediately by the cold dread of the true implication. If it wasn’t him, then the rot was somewhere else, somewhere unexpected.

“That’s what we’re going to find out,” she said, her own resolve hardening, her partnership with him snapping back into its familiar, effective alignment. Together, they bent over the ledger, their heads almost touching in the small pool of light from his desk lamp. They were a team again, hunting a new kind of monster. Her finger traced the lines of signatures. There it was: *Evidence #734-S. Astor, J. Supplemental Report. Received by: Henderson, P. Signed into vault by: Corbin, M.* Her gaze flickered to the next line. Another entry, dated three days after hers. The box for 'Reason for Access' read: *Archival Scan for Secure Digital Redundancy.* It was a plausible, modern-sounding reason, the kind of bureaucratic justification that Henderson would have accepted without question. And the signature in the 'Accessed By' column was a neat, earnest, and tragically familiar scrawl: *Peters, C.*

Corbin swore, a low, savage sound. “The kid,” he breathed, sitting back in his chair as if struck. “It can’t be.” But they both knew it could. Peters, the earnest rookie who had looked like he was going to be sick at the sight of Lily’s body. Peters, who had watched Astor with a wide-eyed reverence that had always bordered on the unsettling. Peters, who had been seduced not by the evil of the story, but by the perceived heroism of its protagonist. He had not betrayed her out of malice. He had betrayed her out of a twisted, obsessive form of worship. He had appointed himself her biographer, the faithful scribe tasked with telling her story with the grandeur he felt it deserved.

Astor closed the ledger. The rage she had felt in Thorne’s office had evaporated, replaced by a hollow, aching pity. Leo had been a fool, a boy chasing a dark fantasy. This felt infinitely worse. This was a betrayal born of devotion. She stood up, her movements stiff. “I’ll handle it,” she said, her voice barely a whisper. She found him where she knew she would, in the canteen, staring into a cup of tea, a notebook open on the table beside him. He looked up as she approached, his face breaking into a bright, eager smile. “Sergeant! You’re back. How was…” His voice trailed off as he saw the look on her face, a look of profound and terrible stillness that he had never seen before.

She didn’t sit. She stood over him, a cold and imposing shadow. “The needle,” she said, her voice a low, conversational murmur that was more terrifying than any shout. “In your post, you described it glinting in the dawn light before it disappeared into the water. It was a good detail. Very cinematic. But it wasn’t in my report. I never wrote that down.” She paused, letting the silence stretch, letting him feel the walls of his fantasy crumbling around him. “That was a detail I told Dr. Thorne, in a secure room, three hundred miles away, twenty-four hours ago. So tell me, Constable. How did you know?”

The colour drained from his face, leaving it a waxy, translucent white. The eager smile collapsed into a slack-jawed mask of horror and disbelief. He stared up at her, his eyes wide with the terror of a disciple whose goddess has just condemned him to hell. His hand, which had been resting on his notebook, began to tremble violently. He opened his mouth to speak, but no words came out, only a small, choked, pathetic gasp. The sound was horribly, sickeningly familiar. It was the sound Julian Croft had made just before the river took his voice forever.

The gasp was a hook in his throat, pulling all the air and colour from him. His face, a moment before alight with a disciple’s earnest devotion, collapsed into a ruin of pure, infantile terror. The notebook, his sacred text, slipped from his numb fingers and clattered onto the linoleum floor, its pages splaying open to reveal his neat, adoring script. He was a boy caught drawing on the walls with his father’s pen, suddenly confronted with the enormity of his transgression. He stared up at Astor, his mouth opening and closing silently, his mind scrambling for a foothold in a world that had just turned to smoke beneath his feet. He was not just caught; he was understood, his pathetic, secret motivations laid bare under the cold, clinical light of her gaze.

Finally, words tore their way out of him, a strangled, whimpering confession. “I… I had to,” he stammered, his voice cracking, tears welling in his wide, terrified eyes. “They were telling the wrong story. Davies, the press… they made it about him. About Croft. But the real story… the important story… was you. What you did. The strength it took. I wanted them to see you the way I do. As a hero. Not as a footnote in his sick book. ‘Epilogue’… it was meant to be the final word. Your word.” He was not confessing to a crime; he was trying to justify a sacred mission, desperate for her to see the purity of his intent, even as the sordid reality of his methods was about to crush him.

A cold, dead certainty settled in Astor’s gut. The theft of the physical report was one thing; this was another. This was active, ongoing. “How, Peters?” she repeated, her voice dropping even lower, a thread of absolute zero in the mundane warmth of the canteen. “How did you hear a private conversation that happened this morning?” The question was a scalpel, and it flayed him. He flinched, curling in on himself as if to ward off a physical blow. “Your car,” he whispered, the words barely audible, laced with shame. “I put a listening device in it. A small one. After the mill… after the Leo case. I was worried about you. You seemed so… alone. I just wanted to make sure you were okay. I listened to your call with Thorne. I heard him, talking to you like you were an experiment, and I heard you, so strong, so in control. And the detail about the needle… it was perfect. It was the proof of the terror, the proof of your victory. I just… I wanted the story to be perfect.”

There it was. The full, pathetic, and profoundly violating truth. He had not done it for a ghoulish audience; he had done it for her, a twisted, obsessive tribute from a secret altar he had built in her name. He saw his surveillance as protection, his plagiarism as piety. The anger that had propelled Astor back to Milton, a cold, hard diamond of rage, finally shattered, leaving behind only a vast, aching void of pity. She looked down at this broken boy, who had loved the idea of her so much he had betrayed the real woman without a second thought, and she felt a weariness that was heavier than any ghost. He was the final, most tragic victim of Julian Croft’s story.

“You didn’t make the story perfect, Peters,” she said, and her voice was not angry, but devastatingly gentle, the voice of a doctor explaining a terminal diagnosis. “You made yourself a part of it. You became another one of his disciples. You think you were writing my story? You were just writing another chapter in his. You took my worst moments, the things that wake me up at night, and you turned them into literature for strangers. You didn’t protect me. You violated me. In the end, you are no different from Leo, trying to build a shrine out of filth, or Thorne, trying to turn a soul into a data point. You all just want a piece of the story. None of you care about the person who had to live it.”

She watched the last light of his deluded righteousness die in his eyes, replaced by the stark, ugly dawn of self-knowledge. He finally saw what he had done, not as a heroic act of curation, but as a low, grubby, unforgivable trespass. He began to sob, not the loud, furious wails of Leo, but the silent, shuddering, hopeless tears of a child who has irrevocably broken his most treasured possession. He had wanted to be her shield, her champion, her apostle. And in the end, he had simply become another monster she had to face. She had stood in the river, in a ruined mill, in a sterile office, fighting the echoes of one man's evil, only to find the most insidious one was sitting in her own canteen, smiling at her over a cup of tea.

Corbin appeared in the doorway, his timing as impeccable and as grim as ever. He had heard enough. He walked over to the table, his heavy presence a final, definitive full stop. He placed a large, gentle hand on Peters’s trembling shoulder. “Come on, son,” he said, his voice gruff but not unkind. “It’s over.” Peters didn’t resist. He allowed Corbin to pull him to his feet, his movements clumsy, his body slack with the utter devastation of his shame. Corbin led him away, a disgraced acolyte being escorted from a temple he had defiled. Astor was left alone in the sudden, profound silence of the canteen, the only sound the faint hum of the fluorescent lights above. On the floor lay the fallen notebook, its pages filled with stolen words and a love so twisted it had become indistinguishable from hate. She looked at it for a long moment, then turned and walked away, leaving it to be swept up with the rest of the day’s refuse. She had purged the last of the infection. But now, her house was well and truly empty.
